## The project

- Research project about how people react, politically, to climate change and weather.

- Personal experiences are easier to understand. And it is an easier route to understanding climate change for everyone experiencing it. More and more people, more and more frequently, more and more intensely.

- Voters increasingly experiences climate change directly through the weather. But they are still influenced by traditional sources as well, notably media coverage (politicians, activists, etc.). They may also point to weather events and make them visible as climate-related events. 
    -   Encounters new climate information all the time
    -   Increasingly in extreme weather events
    -   More and more often, they are attributed to climate change by scientists
    -   But no matter what, there is a growing sense that we are feeling the consequences of climate change, regardless of attribution of individual events (subjective attritution or association)
    -   This means that we experience climate change.

## Media coverage

At the same time, it is not the most accurate way to learn about climate change. There are **other sources of information**. One is education, but it is slow and not dynamic in the short run. A more dynamic influence is media coverage.

## Research question

<br>

> __How are voters’ climate opinions and behavior shaped by media coverage of climate change and personal weather experiences?__

-   Public support is not strong enough
<!-- -   Danish minister of climate says policy must follow 80% (20230814) -->
-   (Increasing) polarization -\> different ways of engaging with new information about climate change
- Personal experience a solution?
    -   Often underplayed 
    -   Can it cut across worldviews?
    -   Can it be the "forceful teacher"?
    -   Let's see...
    
## Research question

<br>

> __How are voters’ climate opinions and behavior shaped by media coverage of climate change and personal weather experiences?__

Focusing on Denmark... Which is many things. Weather experiences are less extreme and dramatic. General climate concern and literacy is high. Political polarization is low (increasing in many places). Also on climate.

## Statistical analysis

- Time series VAR models
- **Verdict: Yes. The public responds to media coverage**
- No sign of reverse causality
- When climate coverage increases by approximately 34, public salience increases by 1 %-point
- Can be anything from 34 articles with low-intensity climate coverage to 1 climate-intensive article (~21 climate articles)

## Who is receptive to media climate coverage? {background-color="white"}

## What's next

- Cross-case / generalizability &rarr; cross-national data with same measurements. Qualify how the world's population responds. Integrated assessment models. 
- Psychological mechanism. Deep learning or superficial salience spikes due to heuristics use.
- Is awareness of the link between experience and climate change necessary?
- Interactions between information flows.
